Events, conferences, podcast and training list up-to-date

A tweet aggregator site dysplaying events, conferences, podcast, certification and courses links that can be useful for data practitioners of all kinds. Hope you enjoy ;)

In @ApacheArrow 0.17.0 we have a new C Data Interface enabling zero-copy in-memory sharing of Arrow data via C FFI. It's a game changer for adding Arrow import/export to libraries without requiring any build or runtime dependencies. Read more: https://t.co/PzQ0odt5TZ

Interested in @rustlang and @ApacheArrow? We have just received a code donation of DataFusion, a native Rust query engine for analytics on Arrow columnar data https://t.co/foGja86Fda

Why should the #pydata programmers have all the fun? We're working to turbocharge R #rstats and @ApacheSpark with @ApacheArrow, read @javierluraschi's blog post about what's in store https://t.co/jeN882JNCy

Apache Calcite

Twitter profile

Announcing Calcite release 1.32! Includes a fix for CVE-2022-39135; switches the spatial engine from ESRI to JTS/proj4j; adds ST_Covers and 64 other spatial functions; adds a CHAR function; and improves the return type of the ARRAY and MULTISET functions. https://t.co/b0Ut2vVdjX

Posted on: 2022-04-11; at: 19:35

Announcing Calcite release 1.30! Includes Babel support for <=> operator; SQL hints for temporal table join; fixtures so that dependent projects can write parser, validator and rules tests; upgrade jsonpath to fix CVE-2021-27568 https://t.co/Bznmk2wo6n

Posted on: 2020-07-27; at: 22:48

An article (from a Calcite committer) describing how @ApacheCalcite is used in @alibaba_cloud's MaxCompute engine. https://t.co/Lk4XOtX7m7

Posted on: 2020-07-27; at: 22:14

An important note on compatibility. In Calcite 1.24, to fix some cyclic class-loading issues, we have deprecated (and suggested replacements for) quite a few rule instances, and some methods. They will disappear in 1.25. Suggest you upgrade to 1.24 and fix your code before 1.25.

Posted on: 2020-07-27; at: 22:06

Announcing Calcite 1.24! Improved Volcano engine (top-down planning to efficiently generate expressions with required physical properties) and Presto JDBC adapter. https://t.co/7voPklrUxq

Posted on: 2020-05-27; at: 19:42

Announcing Calcite 1.23! Major improvements in the performance of the Volcano planning engine, on-demand traits (e.g. sorting), and a ClickHouse dialect for JDBC adapter. And a hundred other things. https://t.co/jFa9Eohjmm

Posted on: 2020-03-11; at: 21:27

Calcite inside: "A SQL Provenance module captures coarse-grained provenance information from SQL queries (input tables and columns affecting the output, with connections modelled as a graph). It is built on top of Apache Calcite." https://t.co/T7NaQ1PBhC

Many questions on #Akka's new license and what it means for #ApacheFlink, which internally uses Akka for cluster coordination. TL;DR: * #Flink's license will ofc not change. * We'll not use Akka 2.7+. * We'll make sure users are not affected. More: https://t.co/drIEDZM8Ih

It is worth noting that these releases change nothing, except for the #log4j version. So if you had, for example, deployed 1.13.3 you can update to 1.13.5 and will only see the logging framework changing.

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

If you didn't know (I didn't until I made this thread), you can delete a notebook cell with 'dd'. And the Interactive Window now supports bringing it back with CMD/Ctrl + Z. Theme: Tangerine https://t.co/ZPBGUuPboV

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

You can also specify the slideshow type for a notebook to turn your notebooks into a nifty presentation. Theme: Night Owl Light https://t.co/RxTMfCfb6z

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

You can now tag cells in Notebooks without having to touch the underlying JSON. Or JASON. This allows us to parameterize them for papermill or customize for nbconvert. Theme: GitHub Light https://t.co/r8Uu58ssM8

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

We heard your feedback that using the word "remote" in our extensions can lead to confusion. So we renamed the Remote-WSL and Remote-Containers extensions to "WSL" and "Dev Containers". <insert joke about the 2 hardest things in computer science> https://t.co/tPK8a8Tnqw

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

PROFILES. Have you tried them? Hopefully so because it's one of the most request features. Ever. Enable with `workbench.experimental.settingsProfiles.enabled`. There is now a customizable profile indicator in the Activity Bar. https://t.co/K5mkBtn8r3

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

Oh and when you're working on code in https://t.co/k0d9Mt7T4o and you decide to continue on in a Codespaces, you don't need to commit your code. Just choose "Continue Working On" and your uncommitted changes travel with you. https://t.co/1RHIFmc5Tx

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

You can now get `code` in your browser omnibox...search bar thingy. This makes it easier to open your GitHub repos in https://t.co/k0d9Mt7T4o. 1. Install the VS Code Chrome/Edge extension https://t.co/0sKTSMHeYX 2. Type `code` 3. Search for your GitHub repo and viola! https://t.co/ptErzh1Vgt

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:13

Hey. You. What's that sound. Oh, that's your Task ending. You can enable it with `audioCues.taskEnded`. Great for improved accessibility and multi-tasking. You can also pin your fave tasks to the top for easy access. Theme: Dracula Soft https://t.co/iLQR8uOgyf

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:12

ğŸ’¡ Quick fix in the terminal? Why not. We've just started rolling this feature out, but today you can get quick fixes when you try to run a process on a port that's in use, botch a git command, forget to push your branch, or even just to help you create a PR. Theme: Cobalt2 https://t.co/qpLSTBUr22

If you ğŸ¶ still haven't found what you're looking for ğŸ¶ when using Search, we added the ability to view results as a tree. Just toggle between the list and tree views with the list/tree icon in the top corner of the search view. Theme: Tweed Light (Rainglow) https://t.co/HhljrANCx5

Posted on: 2022-10-06; at: 18:12

A key learning in introducing typing in a large Python codebase? Go at it incrementally. A single `big-bang`, one PR approach is impossible to review and results in constant rebasing and fixing of conflicts.

Posted on: 2022-11-08; at: 17:00

By being lightweight enough for development and modeling the entire graph of assets that surrounds a machine learning model, Dagster enables ML engineers to try out ideas faster, productionize more easily, and understand how the models perform over time. https://t.co/Vj4TSkjIMG

Posted on: 2022-10-31; at: 17:03

Improving the pipeline often has a larger impact on the final result than improving the models themselves. Dagster can dramatically accelerate the speed you improve your ML models, reduce errors and downtime, and help understand how your ML assets are faring in production.

Posted on: 2022-10-31; at: 17:03

To train an ML model involves massive, repeatable data transformations, and frequent iteration to try out changes without interfering with the data and models that youâ€™ve deployed to production. An ML model is only as good as the pipeline that trains and evaluates it.

Posted on: 2022-10-31; at: 17:03

Did you know that half of all pipelines built on Dagster incorporate machine learning models? There is a reason why Dagster is the tool of choice for sophisticated pipelines used in data science and predictive analytics. @s_ryz explores the reasons why. https://t.co/Vj4TSkjIMG

The Dask distributed scheduler can now dump its cluster state to arbitrary fsspec-compatible filesystems (like S3 or GCS), allowing for easier debugging.

Posted on: 2022-03-18; at: 22:22

Other doc improvements include better API docs of string, categorical, and datetime accessors for DataFrames, and updated explanations of how Daskâ€™s distributed scheduler assigns tasks to workers. Thanks to @scharlottej13, @jcristharif, keewis, and Gabe Joseph! https://t.co/GFdzF9Iwqm

Posted on: 2022-03-18; at: 22:22

There have been a number of improvements to documentation. There is a new new page documenting the interactive Dask dashboard thanks to @ncclementi https://t.co/cTd9tjSy1S

Posted on: 2022-03-18; at: 22:22

Dask Bag now supports out-of-memory sampling using reservoir sampling, thanks to Daniel Mesejo-LeÃ³n

Posted on: 2022-03-18; at: 22:22

The Dask team is happy to announce the release of version 2022.3.0 today! https://t.co/Ju2UkczhkI This release includes contributions from 28 people, including 7 new contributors. Some highlights ğŸ§µ:

Posted on: 2022-02-25; at: 21:50

Thanks to @JSignell for managing this release, and to everyone who contributed across the Dask org. We had 27 contributors this release, including 6 first time contributors! Interested in contributing to Dask? Check out our list of good first issues here: https://t.co/brsn2BzwqH

Posted on: 2022-02-25; at: 21:50

4. This release drops support for Python 3.7, in accordance with NEP29 (https://t.co/MC2Mi9Rjl5).

Posted on: 2022-02-25; at: 21:50

3. When a Dask worker runs low on RAM, it will spill excess data to disk. With this release, you can now configure how much disk space a worker is allowed to use for storing excess data (thanks @ncclementi !). https://t.co/MYX0XdT61U

Posted on: 2022-02-25; at: 21:50

2. Dask clients now support preload scripts, making it easier to customize client initialization (thanks to @darthbith). Previously this feature was only supported by the scheduler & workers. https://t.co/6uFt9wfH0x

Posted on: 2022-02-25; at: 21:50

1. Dask DataFrame has expanded Pandas coverage. - `std()` now works for datetime Series. - `pivot_table()` now supports `first` & `last` aggregations. Thanks to new contributors Ben Glossner and Knut Nordanger!

Posted on: 2022-02-25; at: 21:50

The Dask team is happy to announce the release of 2022.02.1 today! https://t.co/OJkbpNCxZG Some highlights ğŸ§µ: https://t.co/FIuQsIC0vh

Posted on: 2022-02-17; at: 14:28

Come to the @SciPyConf in July! Talk submissions close February 22nd https://t.co/66u1iRBuAL

Posted on: 2022-02-17; at: 12:28

Are you deploying Dask on Kubernetes with the Helm Chart? If so you can now configure multiple worker groups with different hardware configurations. This enables running high memory or GPU workers and using annotations to run specific tasks on them. https://t.co/JhrY3P8k5v https://t.co/dbiN2MBmwj

Posted on: 2022-02-11; at: 20:02

And finally, thanks to @JSignell for release managing this week!

Posted on: 2022-02-11; at: 19:59

Posted on: 2022-02-11; at: 19:59

Dask has new documentation on visualizing High Level Graphs, check it out here: https://t.co/NDfQ1lm72c Thanks for this, @DataNerdery! https://t.co/TePL12T3K1

Posted on: 2022-02-11; at: 19:59

Zarr and Parquet output both got performance enhancements: to_zarr now allows you to write to specific subregions of an existing dataset (thanks @chrisroat), and to_parquet now uses High Level Graphs, allowing for better graph communication and optimization (thanks @_rjzamora).

Quantum computing package Qiskit accelerates with Dask. This is a good example of using Dask's futures interface for general purpose parallelism. https://t.co/wv4ztdNa1Y

Posted on: 2022-01-28; at: 21:07

More Dask routines have been converted to use High Level Graphs, allowing for faster construction and communication of task graphs, as well as higher-level optimizations. In particular, you should see performance improvements in "dask.array.from_array" and DataFrame reductions.

Posted on: 2022-01-28; at: 21:07

Dask DataFrame read_parquet's performance for remotely-stored-data has been improved. This will provide faster reads for both the "pyarrow" and "fastparquet" engines, thanks to @_rjzamora! https://t.co/GfQawjedWX

ğŸŸ¢ The solutions are filtered, clustered, and reranked to a set of 10 candidate programs that are submitted for external assessment. This automated system is similar to the usual human process of debugging, compiling, passing tests and then submitting: https://t.co/NyvnRkzePB

ğŸ”¢ AlphaCode is pre-trained on selected public @GitHub code and fine-tuned on our relatively small competitive programming dataset. At evaluation time, millions of diverse C++ and Python programs are created for each problem, orders of magnitude larger than previous work. https://t.co/6sBDyPIsYi

The ability to skip irrelevant files is the source of one of the biggest performance gains when querying Delta Lakes. Delta Lake stores file metadata in the #transactionlog so it can rapidly identify the files with relevant data for a given query! ğŸ™Œâ¡ï¸ https://t.co/StaUJc4WzB https://t.co/nEUIrVNSUa

It's time for the #ApacheDruid Tip of the Week: Streaming data into Druid can cause your data to be stored in lots of small segments. The great thing about Druid is that you can use compaction to optimize your segments and improve performance. https://t.co/Gyw42M57Zs

@halvarflake There is a Discord, https://t.co/Ow8Gvp9w2p, and indeed you will need the ICU extension to deal with time zones. Can be INSTALLed for the official binaries or enabled in the compilation by setting BUILD_ICU=1

Posted on: 2023-01-05; at: 08:50

@halvarflake But you can't use the auto reader then. See here for an example: https://t.co/iion0YJY6N

Posted on: 2023-01-05; at: 08:49

@halvarflake You can try our experimental parallel CSV reader with `SET experimental_parallel_csv=true;`

Posted on: 2023-01-04; at: 14:11

@halvarflake I get https://t.co/BSQqtS0IKN

Posted on: 2023-01-04; at: 14:09

@halvarflake You can use `epoch_ms` for epoch ms to timestamp and `to_timestamp` for epoch s to timestamp. Should probably clean up those names. But if I have a file like ms,s 1672840614017,1672841184 I can do this SELECT epoch_ms(ms) ts1, to_timestamp(s) ts2 FROM "timestamps.csv";

Read our full findings, including our analysis of some seemingly contradictory responses, by downloading the (free) complete report ğŸ‘‰ https://t.co/JCV3nA9XRE

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 21:29

Do data practitioners speak the same language? It depends: In aggregate Java was the language of the data team, but Python, SQL, Scala, and R all see plenty of use. No language was used by an overwhelming majority.ğŸ‘‡

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 21:29

Are data landscapes settled? No way: Respondents were planning an average of 2.5 new data initiatives each for the next quarter. A survey of data stack technologies indicated a wide array of stack compositions.ğŸ‘‡

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 21:29

What exactly is data quailty? Thereâ€™s some disagreement on that: three-quarters of resopndents said they were currently performing data validationâ€¦ including many who indicated they didnâ€™t have any active data quality. ğŸ‘‡

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 21:29

There are DQ processes in placeâ€¦ sometimes: there was a roughly equal split between respondents who indicated active #dataquality processes were in place and those who have planned but not implement or are not planning DQ. ğŸ‘‡

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 21:29

Not everyone is on the same page: 55% of data engineers and 50% of data scientists rated their trust in their data as â€œhigh,â€ but only 34% of data analysts felt the same .ğŸ‘‡

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 21:29

â€œData scientists spend too much time on data prepâ€ is a cliche, but itâ€™s still true: more than a quarter of respondents cited this as a top symptom of #dataquality problems. ğŸ‘‡

Posted on: 2023-01-20; at: 09:57

Posted on: 2023-01-20; at: 09:57

Posted on: 2021-04-28; at: 15:29

Table scans (new in Mondayâ€™s release) let you make trade-offs in view materialization: - Simple queries = fast (more write-time work) - Complex queries = flexible (more read-time work) SELECT A, B FROM table WHERE a < 10 AND B = 'v1'; Learn more: https://t.co/w5O8Hr1n23

Posted on: 2021-04-27; at: 16:39

Inline lambda functions (new in yesterdayâ€™s release) give SQL a whole extra layer of expressivity. Compose & nest with any other functions: CREATE STREAM reduced AS SELECT ID, reduce(numbers, 2, (s, x) => s + x) FROM xs; Learn more: https://t.co/bfsIP1rGpn

In ksqlDB 0.8.0, lookup tables just got really easy to make. `latest_by_offset` simply retains the last value it sees for queries: CREATE TABLE my_view AS SELECT name, latest_by_offset(location) FROM movements GROUP BY name EMIT CHANGES;

Ever want to just restart your ksqlDB CLI session from scratch? `terminate all` in ksqlDB 0.7.1 will cascadingly terminate all running queries. Very handy.

â—ï¸The process also has some limitations and areas for improvement, such as limitations on the number of parallel CI processes and the lack of support for variables or XComs.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 16:13

ğŸ•° The process is completed in 5-7 minutes and has improved the testing velocity from 1 hour to 7 minutes, reduced human mistakes, and eliminated database conflicts.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 16:13

ğŸ’» The process involves creating a new database in Redshift for each commit in a Pull Request (PR), generating data structures and assets based on the pre-production state, running new migrations using Flyway, and executing workflows through a script to bypass the scheduler.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 16:13

ğŸ¤– The article is about the implementation of a Continuous Integration (CI) process for a data warehouse using Airflow, Flyway, and Redshift.

ğŸ’¡The architecture includes layers for data ingestion/acquisition, data lake, metadata, caching & indexing, and data engineering. Transformations happen through Bronze, Silver, and Gold tables.

ğŸ”’Key features of a Data Lakehouse include transaction support, schema enforcement, governance & audit, BI support, open storage format & support for all types of data.

ğŸ•°ï¸ Airflow was used to automate the runs of Cloud Functions by scheduling jobs based on the frequency in the main table. With Airflow, monitoring, retry, alerts & passing parameters became possible.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:34

ğŸ’» Cloud Functions, including Snowflake to GCS, GCS to Google sheet & EdgeDB update & Push Notifications, were implemented to improve the workflow.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:34

ğŸ’¾ To avoid re-running & check data, EdgeDB was used to store every job status & GCS was used to store data.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:34

ğŸ’¾ Replacing cron jobs with Cloud Functions solved the issue of resource exhaustion & also provided logging through Cloud Logging.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:34

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:14

ğŸ“Š Prefetching is a technique that starts downloading one or more subsequent files while processing the current file, avoiding download delay for all but the first file. This technique is used by many frameworks for accelerating data ingestion, such as PyTorch and TensorFlow.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:14

ğŸš€ Some apps prioritize time to first sample while others focus on minimizing average sequential read time, total processing time, and average random read time.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:14

ğŸ’» Different metrics are used to compare the performance of different methods for pulling large files from Amazon S3 in Python.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:14

ğŸ¢ When working with large files, it's recommended to use a file format that supports partial reads & choose a sweet spot between file size (somewhere between a few MBs to a few hundred MBs).

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 14:14

ğŸ“ˆ Streamline your big data file consumption with efficient methods from cloud storage. By @RandChaim https://t.co/VM5oWsNoMK

ğŸ’¼ Data is treated as a product with a product owner, consumer consultations, release cycles, and quality agreements. and Federated governance.

ğŸ’¡Data Mesh follows 4 principles: Domain ownership, Data as a product, Self-service, and Federated governance.

ğŸ”¥It resolves the challenges faced in traditional data and analytics approaches such as centralized data warehouses and lack of compatibility.

ğŸ’¼ To implement code-based ETL successfully, assess your current process, build a team of experts, test and validate the code, and monitor the process for optimization.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 13:12

ğŸ’» One key advantage of code-based ETL is the ability to deploy to the cloud for cost savings and scalability. Thorough testing and validation are crucial for accurate data and efficient processes.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 13:12

ğŸ” With code-based ETL, you can perform complex transformations, automate the process, collaborate with a team, and take advantage of libraries and frameworks.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 13:12

ğŸ’» ETL is a critical step in data processing. Code-based ETL is gaining popularity due to its flexibility and control.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 13:12

ğŸ”‘ Unlock your data's potential with code-based ETL: more flexible, efficient, and cost-effective. By Ignacio Chartier https://t.co/lk1Y41xCjM

ğŸŒ Follow @moderndatastack or https://t.co/7q8hHvwWz3 to stay updated with the latest in modern data stack. #data #moderndatastack #dataengineering #datascience #dataanalytics

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 12:19

ğŸ” Remember, data skew is caused by data shuffling, so be mindful of key-based operations like groupBy and joins.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 12:19

ğŸ’» To handle data skew, try the "salting" technique. This article also explains two other ways to handle data skew in Apache Spark.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 12:19

ğŸ” To identify data skew, look at the Spark Web UI's Stages tab. If some partitions hang and the max column has a much larger value than the medium, you have a data skew issue.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 12:19

ğŸ’» Apache Spark is a powerful tool, but sometimes it runs slow. One common cause is data skew, where partitions have uneven data to process.

Posted on: 2023-01-31; at: 12:19

â¡ï¸ Speed up your Apache Spark jobs by tackling data skew with our ultimate guide. By @ChengzhiZhao https://t.co/PzW7MKcMpe

ğŸ¤” OLTP is different from Online Analytical Processing (OLAP), which is used for data analysis and decision-making.

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 15:12

ğŸ’¾ OLTP systems use databases to store transaction data and have high volume, high availability, frequent data modifications, fast response times, and data integrity.

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 15:12

ğŸ“Š Transaction data, like incoming and outgoing payments, is treated differently because it has specific characteristics like high normalization and consistency.

Posted on: 2023-01-30; at: 15:12

ğŸ’» Online Transaction Processing (OLTP) involves processing multiple transactions simultaneously, such as online banking and e-commerce sales.

ğŸ¤” BigQuery has been the top choice for small data warehouses. AWS may change this if they remove the minimum 60-second period.

ğŸ” In summary, while Redshift Serverless may offer some benefits, it's important to consider the costs and trade-offs carefully before choosing it as a data warehouse solution.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 14:53

ğŸ’° However, after initial calculations and usage, the author found a significant decrease in the trial money account. The reason is, Redshift Serverless charges on a per-second basis (with a 60-second minimum charge). This can add up to a lot of money for small data warehouses.

ğŸ’¡ Feature engineering is the process of creating new features from existing ones. It's an important step in data preprocessing.

âš–ï¸ Normalizing data refers to the process of scaling the numeric data attributes into a 0 to 1 range. This is important because some machine learning algorithms are sensitive to the scale of the data.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 14:28

ğŸ’¦ Cleaning data refers to the process of removing or correcting errors, inconsistencies, and missing values in the data. This is important because these issues can lead to inaccurate or unreliable results.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 14:28

ğŸ” Data preprocessing is a crucial step in any data science project. It involves cleaning, normalizing, and feature engineering the data to make it suitable for analysis and modelling.

ğŸ”Œ There are over 30 connectors that Presto supports, such as BigQuery, Cassandra, Elasticsearch, and MongoDB connectors.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 12:30

ğŸ’» Presto's architecture consists of a coordinator, worker nodes, connectors, catalogs, schemas, tables, and more.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 12:30

ğŸ›£ï¸ Presto is not a general-purpose relational database, it was not designed to handle OLTP, but it is great for data warehousing and analytics.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 12:30

ğŸ” It originated in Facebook as a result of Hive taking a long time to execute large queries.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 12:30

ğŸš€ Presto (or PrestoDB) is a distributed, fast, reliable SQL query engine that fetches data from heterogeneous data sources querying large sets of data, and processes it in memory.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 12:30

ğŸ“Š The power of big data processing with Presto - the distributed, fast, and reliable SQL query engine. By Bhargav Maddikera https://t.co/0duEiNq1jg

ğŸ“ The data warehouse layer applies functional business rules to the data and the Data Mart layer presents the data to the end users.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 11:15

ğŸ“ A common data warehouse architecture is the three-layer approach which includes a Staging area/Landing zone, Data warehouse layer, and Data Mart layer.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 11:15

ğŸ’¾ Data warehouse and Data Lake architecture are two ways to implement BI. Data warehouse uses a schema-on-write approach, while Data Lake uses a schema-on-read approach. Each has its own advantages and disadvantages depending on the use case.

Posted on: 2023-01-25; at: 11:15

ğŸ” BI provides a single version of the truth, descriptive analytics, and diagnostic analytics. However, it does not predict future outcomes.

Hi all! This is @ralfgommers. This Wed, October 14th at 1pm PDT the NumPy team is hosting a virtual town hall to discuss the past and present of the project, governance, community outreach, and other important topics. For more details, please see here: https://t.co/cbBVOdP1qR 1/2

Posted on: 2020-09-27; at: 23:33

@davenquinn Yeah, the myth of meritocracy in tech â€“ and OSS especially â€“ is something the community has been grappling with for a long time, e.g. here's a post from 2014: https://t.co/vSZYTHW7bc Awareness of the problems here has grown a lot, but we still have long way to go. -@vorpalsmith

Posted on: 2020-09-26; at: 22:27

And on that note, the NumPy team will also be organizing a "town hall" soon, to hear your thoughts and answer questions in more depth than Twitter allows. We'll post an update ASAP once we have the details sorted. (end of thread)

Posted on: 2020-09-26; at: 22:27

OK. That's what we have to say right now. If there's anything urgent that we missed, then please let us know. But otherwise, for the next while we're going to focus on listening.

Posted on: 2020-09-26; at: 22:27

On the other hand, to everyone who's been attacking and harassing our critics: STOP. They're making important points, and even if they werenâ€™t, abuse is never ok. We should have said this much sooner. We're sorry we didn't.

Posted on: 2020-09-26; at: 22:27

Also, thank you to everyone who's been helping us understand our screw-ups and how to do better â€” we've learned a lot, and we appreciate you.

Posted on: 2020-09-26; at: 22:27

We've also made a bunch of screw-ups these last two weeks here on Twitter. One was that the @numpy_team account had two critics blocked. They've been unblocked. We wantâ€”no, needâ€”dialogue, and blocking critics does the opposite. We deeply apologize.

Posted on: 2020-09-26; at: 22:27

Our team makeup has not and does not reflect our users or the broader society, and this is a serious failing. We're not proud of this. We're working to change it. But we still have a long way to go, and you're right to hold us accountable.

Posted on: 2020-09-26; at: 22:27

First: many have pointed out that our recent paper's all-male authorship list shows a major problem with diversity and inclusion. These critics are 100% correct.

Posted on: 2020-09-26; at: 22:27

Hi all. This is @vorpalsmith. The @numpy_team's been having a lot of discussions behind the scenes about how we can engage better here on Twitter and in general, and I wanted to give you an update on that. (1/n)

Posted on: 2020-09-24; at: 00:08

@ralfgommers @cziscience We are open to dialogue and welcome every opportunity to connect with organizations representing and supporting women and minorities in tech and science. 7/7

Posted on: 2020-09-24; at: 00:07

@ralfgommers @cziscience As a result of several initiatives aimed at community development and engagement led by Inessa Pawson and Ralf Gommers, NumPy has received a number of valuable contributions from underrepresented groups in OSS in 2020 (see the list of contributors https://t.co/ijhoYgoQhv). 6/7

Posted on: 2020-09-24; at: 00:06

Offering employment opportunities is an effective way to attract and retain diverse talent in open source. Therefore, @ralfgommers used two-thirds of our @cziscience grant that became available in Dec 2019 to employ Melissa Weber MendonÃ§a and Mars Lee. 5/7

Posted on: 2020-09-24; at: 00:05

Contributing to open source has always been a pastime in which most historically marginalized groups, especially women, faced more obstacles to participate due to a number of societal constraints and expectations. 4/7

Posted on: 2020-09-24; at: 00:04

Being an international team from the onset, we recognize the value of collaborating with individuals from diverse backgrounds and expertise. 3/7

Posted on: 2020-09-24; at: 00:04

A culture where everyone is welcomed, supported, and valued is at the core of the NumPy project. 2/7

Posted on: 2020-09-23; at: 23:54

In light of the foregoing discussion on social media after publication of the NumPy paper in Nature and the concerns raised about the state of diversity and inclusion on the NumPy team, we would like to issue the following statement: https://t.co/ijhoYgoQhv 1/7

Posted on: 2020-09-16; at: 16:27

NumPy includes protocols to facilitate interoperability with external libraries like PyTorch, Dask, and JAX. Through such features, NumPy provides a standard API for tensor computation and is a central coordinating mechanism between array technologies in Python. https://t.co/Yer4qBy8Ya

Posted on: 2020-09-16; at: 16:27

The array programming foundation provided by NumPy, combined with a rich surrounding ecosystem of tools â€” inside of IPython or Jupyter â€” forms an interactive environment ideally suited to exploratory data analysis. https://t.co/pmoeiejPuQ

Posted on: 2020-09-16; at: 16:27

NumPy provides an easily readable, expressive, high-level API for array programming. It takes care of the underlying mechanics that make operations fast. https://t.co/ekJ6Z9yyDY

@__qualname__ @teoliphant 8/8 Objects need the GIL, but memory management is tricky in either case, so... (again pygeos hacks around this partially, IIRC).

Posted on: 2020-04-09; at: 04:43

@__qualname__ @teoliphant 7/8 Subclassing ndarray could hack some things, but may turn out to be disastrous.

Posted on: 2020-04-09; at: 04:37

@__qualname__ @teoliphant 6/8 We could discuss allowing statically allocated PyObjects if their size is fixed and they are immutable.

Posted on: 2020-04-09; at: 04:35

@__qualname__ @teoliphant 5/8 However, this will not take place in the nearest future. So for now, using Python objects is your best bet.

Posted on: 2020-04-09; at: 03:40

@__qualname__ @teoliphant 4/8 Homogeneously typed object arrays will be a thing eventually, this would allow you to specialize ufuncs (better).

Posted on: 2020-04-09; at: 03:39

@__qualname__ @teoliphant 3/8 pygeos does exactly what you are asking for. We suggest checking out what they are doing.

Posted on: 2020-04-09; at: 03:38

@__qualname__ @teoliphant 2/8 Then you can store it already with dtype=object.

Posted on: 2020-04-09; at: 03:37

@__qualname__ @teoliphant 1/8 The solution is to use a Python Object which holds your data (this adds two fields in C, that should be irrelevant).

Posted on: 2022-07-19; at: 22:21

Bodo has just become a pandas and NumFOCUS financial supporter. Bodo is a just in time compiler that allows executing pandas code in a parallel way without running the pandas underlying code based on NumPy. This should help run pandas code faster and at scale. 1/2

Posted on: 2021-01-19; at: 13:33

Openpyxl is not yet supported for a long time in pandas for reading excel files, so if you encounter any issues when switching from xlrd to openpyxl, please report them! -> https://t.co/T96ltReNMY

Posted on: 2021-01-19; at: 13:33

Starting with pandas 1.2, we use "openpyxl" by default if available, and otherwise raise a warning. "xlrd" is still supported for reading old .xls files (thanks to @chriswithers13 for maintaining it!).

Posted on: 2021-01-19; at: 13:33

âš ï¸ Important note for pandas users reading excel files! âš ï¸ Please ensure you have the "openpyxl" package installed. Previously, pandas used the "xlrd" package by default. But "xlrd" is only meant to read old xls files, not for .xlsx files. See warning at https://t.co/y6jAebcYeS https://t.co/zBZZs2zBrq

ğŸ“¢ Sprints What are Sprints? Development sprints offer an opportunity to enhance and contribute to open-source projects in a focused session with the project maintainers. It is a fun exercise that helps open-source projects improve with the help of the open-source community.

Posted on: 2022-11-22; at: 16:58

@ashridha @SmitShah_11 @bargava @_swanand 1. You configure the data model 2. You run queries in terms of that data model 3. Cube generates the SQL for the upstream database or DWH for you

Posted on: 2022-11-22; at: 16:55

@SmitShah_11 You'll have to set up the data schema and run high-level, declaratively defined queries. In exchange, you'll get sub-second latency for arbitrary queries and zero DWH costs thanks to our caching layer. Do try Cube and feel free to ping @igorlukanin if any issues arise

Posted on: 2022-11-22; at: 16:53

@SmitShah_11 Hey there! Cube was already mentioned a couple of times in this threadâ€”but let us assure it would work great for this use case. Check this post if you'd like to wrap your head around Cube in minutes: https://t.co/j9xX5V21Kz

Posted on: 2022-11-22; at: 15:27

Also, you can put Cube in between Hasura and your transactional database. In return, you'll get low-latency (50-300ms p90) responses to arbitrary queriesâ€”still working with a unified GraphQL interface provided by Hasura https://t.co/7XvkvSORDN

Posted on: 2022-11-22; at: 15:27

With Cube's SQL, REST, and GraphQL APIs, data integration is easy. If you already deliver data to end-user applications with GraphQL, you can naturally blend Cube in. See how Cube works with Hasura GraphQL Engine by @HasuraHQ: https://t.co/zlA4ItNWPh #graphql #hasura #webdev
